pull.title: contrib: update macOS SDK to Xcode-26.1.1-17B100

events.body: The following sections might be updated with supplementary metadata relevant to reviewers and maintainers. ### Code Coverage & Benchmarks For details see: https://corecheck.dev/bitcoin/bitcoin/pulls/34036. ### Reviews See [the guideline](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#code-review) for information on the review process. | Type | Reviewers | | ---- | --------- | | Concept ACK | [theuni](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/34036#issuecomment-3751106918) | If your review is incorrectly listed, please copy-paste <!--meta-tag:bot-skip--> into the comment that the bot should ignore.
Forgot to bump the CI, according to the touched files of the last bump: `git show 8ea45e626e5a0482ee11d4376f961d8126ce7c7b --stat`?
Yea. However no point until the SDK is uploaded, and no point doing that until we've got determinism.
The new tarball should become available some time today.

The CI failure does not appear to be specific to Qt.

For instance, `gmake -C depends zeromq HOST=arm64-apple-darwin` also fails.

verification.payload:
tree bd7ba4f9c67c1bfb4932a186ce247746f5c78056
parent 1d3243806da6db8bd13e6b20906628ed434362b6
author fanquake <fanquake@gmail.com> 1765294958 +0000
committer fanquake <fanquake@gmail.com> 1769593973 +0000

contrib: update macOS SDK to Xcode-26.1.1-17B100

events.message: contrib: update macOS SDK to Xcode-26.1.1-17B100

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -15,14 +15,14 @@ When complete, it will have produced `Bitcoin-Core.zip`.
 A free Apple Developer Account is required to proceed.
 
 Our macOS SDK can be extracted from
-[Xcode_15.xip](https://download.developer.apple.com/Developer_Tools/Xcode_15/Xcode_15.xip).
+[Xcode_26.1.1_Apple_silicon.xip](https://download.developer.apple.com/Developer_Tools/Xcode_26.1.1/Xcode_26.1.1_Apple_silicon.xip).
comments.body: This implies dropping `x86_64-apple-darwin`? Or do you just want to try the Apple Silicon target first to see if it's deterministic?

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -51,8 +51,8 @@ path to `Xcode.app` (extracted in the previous stage) as the first argument.
 ./contrib/macdeploy/gen-sdk.py '/path/to/Xcode.app'
 ```
 
-The generated archive should be: `Xcode-15.0-15A240d-extracted-SDK-with-libcxx-headers.tar`.
-The `sha256sum` should be `95b00dc41fa090747dc0a7907a5031a2fcb2d7f95c9584ba6bccdb99b6e3d498`.
+The generated archive should be: `Xcode-26.1.1-17B100-extracted-SDK-with-libcxx-headers.tar`.
+The `sha256sum` should be `9600fa93644df674ee916b5e2c8a6ba8dacf631996a65dc922d003b98b5ea3b1`.
comments.body:
Checksum matches on my Apple M4 Pro with macOS 26.2.

I also got this sha256 sum on Ubuntu x86_64.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -15,14 +15,14 @@ When complete, it will have produced `Bitcoin-Core.zip`.
 A free Apple Developer Account is required to proceed.
 
 Our macOS SDK can be extracted from
-[Xcode_15.xip](https://download.developer.apple.com/Developer_Tools/Xcode_15/Xcode_15.xip).
+[Xcode_26.1.1_Apple_silicon.xip](https://download.developer.apple.com/Developer_Tools/Xcode_26.1.1/Xcode_26.1.1_Apple_silicon.xip).
comments.body:
> This implies dropping x86_64-apple-darwin?

No, this isn't dropping support for any build targets. IIrc this is the version of Xcode that only runs on Apple Silicon, which I chose because the download is smaller, and this doesn't make any difference to the extracted SDK.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -51,8 +51,8 @@ path to `Xcode.app` (extracted in the previous stage) as the first argument.
 ./contrib/macdeploy/gen-sdk.py '/path/to/Xcode.app'
 ```
 
-The generated archive should be: `Xcode-15.0-15A240d-extracted-SDK-with-libcxx-headers.tar`.
-The `sha256sum` should be `95b00dc41fa090747dc0a7907a5031a2fcb2d7f95c9584ba6bccdb99b6e3d498`.
+The generated archive should be: `Xcode-26.1.1-17B100-extracted-SDK-with-libcxx-headers.tar`.
+The `sha256sum` should be `9600fa93644df674ee916b5e2c8a6ba8dacf631996a65dc922d003b98b5ea3b1`.
comments.body: Matches for me as well on Ubuntu x86_64.
